title: How to Identify a Siberian Husky

steps.title: Check the dog's size.
steps.content: Check the dog's size. Siberian Huskies are medium-sized members of the working group. steps.title: Look at the ears.
steps.content: Look at the ears. Siberians have thick ears that are triangular. They are medium in size, set high, strongly erect, and slightly rounded at the tips. [5] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: Inspect the eyes.
steps.content: Inspect the eyes. The eyes of a Siberian Husky are almond-shaped and moderately spaced. They may be blue or brown, or a dog may have one of each color. [6] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: Notice the tail.
steps.content: Notice the tail. Siberian Huskies don't have curled tails; however, their tails may stand sickle when the dog is at attention. [7] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source The tail usually hangs down from the back otherwise. It is fox-brush-shaped and well-furred, the fur medium in length. [8] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: See the dog's overall body structure.
steps.content: See the dog's overall body structure. A Siberian's body is well-furred and moderately compact. They have firm muscles, a straight back, and a smooth, seemingly effortless gait. [9] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: Check the length of the coat.
steps.content: Check the length of the coat. Siberian Huskies have double coats of medium length, giving the dog a well-furred appearance. The undercoat is dense and soft, though it may be hidden during shedding season. [10] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source The outer coat is straight and somewhat smooth lying. [11] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: Understand that a Siberian's coat may be any color.
steps.content: Understand that a Siberian's coat may be any color. A Siberian Husky may be any color, from black to solid white. [12] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source Other colors seen include grey, brown, and red.

steps.title: Notice white markings.
steps.content: Notice white markings. Many Siberians have white markings. These can be found on the tail, stomach, chest, and legs. It is common to see a variety of markings on the head, as well. [13] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club Expert knowledge, resources and advice for all things dog-related. Go to source

steps.title: Look for the agouti coat.
steps.content: Look for the agouti coat. "Agouti" is a special term used to describe a Siberian Husky with a coat of "alternating bands of light and dark" along the fur of the coat. [14] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club The American Kennel Club (AKC) is a purebred dog pedigree registry in the United States. The AKC advocates for the responsible ownership of dogs and promotes purebred dog events, such as the Westminster Dog Show. Go to source Not all Siberians are seen with this coat resembling wolf-coloring, but it may appear.

steps.title: Notice high energy levels.
steps.content: Notice high energy levels. Every dog has its own energy level, regardless of breed. However, Siberian Huskies tend to be more energetic than others. As sled dogs, it is natural for them to need lots of exercise to release their energy. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Watch for independent thinking.
steps.content: Watch for independent thinking. Siberians are intelligent but won't necessarily be quick to follow commands. They are clever and good at solving problems, so training may take some extra effort. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Look for a desire to be around others.
steps.content: Look for a desire to be around others. Siberian Huskies are pack dogs. They enjoy being around people and other dogs, if they have been properly socialized. [17] X Research source

steps.title: See if the dog has a high prey drive.
steps.content: See if the dog has a high prey drive. Siberians enjoy the company of people and other canines, but when it comes to other small animals, Siberians can demonstrate a high prey drive. [18] X Research source It is important to train a Siberian Husky to get along with these other animals.

steps.title: Check for friendliness.
steps.content: Check for friendliness. Siberian Huskies are generally very friendly. They can make good family pets if they are socialized and get enough of an energy release. [19] X Research source
